title: What is the longest part of the cell cycle? - Quora

response.answer_text: In most of the dividing cells it's the G1 phase...but in cardiac cells or neurons which are not dividing the longest phase is theGo phase.This answer may differ in some special cases in human biology like the oocytes of vertebrates enter into an inactive stage called dictyotene which is the longest in their cycle.Also in embryonic cells that are rapidly dividing G1 phase lasts only for a few minutes.

Interphase(I-Phase) It is interval between two successive divisions of a eukaryotic cell in which growth and synthetic activities prepare a cell and it's nucleus to divide again. It is a non-dividing phase and also known as resting phase. Why it is the longest phase?  Cell doubles up it's components and prepares itself for cell division. Synthesis and storage of energy rich compounds, especially ATP. Replication of DNA, division of centrosomes and formation of two centriole pairs in animal cells and cells of some primitive plants. Intermitotic interphase utilises 75–95% of the generation time(consider 24 hours is required to divide, then it is about 22.15 hours in humans) It has three stages namely G1, S and G2.
